NewsLines.HeadLine: Eurostocks wither as German election result weighs

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MARKETS-EUROPE-STOCKS (UPDATE 3):Eurostocks wither as German election result weighs

body.p: By Paul Richardson

LONDON, Sept 23 (Reuters) - European shares were broadly lower by mid-session on Monday as disappointment about the result of the German election added to the already gloomy tone set by worries about the global economy and corporate profits.
Losses were led by German blue-chips like Munich Re, which sank 9.1 percent, Deutsche Bank, which lost 5.1 percent and DaimlerChrysler, which fell three percent.
But Germany also provided the biggest gainer, consumer brands company Beiersdorf leaping 15 percent on reports that its larger U.S. rival Procter & Gamble was considering buying a stake in the firm.
Frankfurt's DAX index was down 3.3 percent by 1045 GMT on Monday, a day after German voters returned the incumbent government to power with a sharply reduced majority.
"One is tempted to think the fall is on back of the German elections given it's not best of outcomes with such a narrow majority," said Gareth Evans, European equity strategy at ING Barings.

"Certainly (opposition candidate Edmund) Stoiber would have been better received by the market because of his plans for structural reform. The government has not got much of a majority so we can't expect much on reform going forward," Evans added.
The FTSE Eurotop 300 index of pan-European blue chips was down 1.7 percent at 835, as losers beat gainers by five-to-one, while the narrower DJ Euro Stoxx 50 index was off 2.1 percent at 2,260.
U.S. futures added to the gloom, indicating both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq Composite would open lower.
Fund managers said overall sentiment continued to be undermined by broader worries.

"The market is dealing with five or six insecurities at the moment -- political, military, economic, corporate and general negative sentiment," said Lex Werkheim, fund manager at Eureffect Asset Management in Amsterdam.
"It's all too much for the market to go up at the moment. We need some of those insecurities to come out into the open before the market can recover," Werkheim said.
CHIPS ARE DOWN

Tech shares were dented after JDS Uniphase Corp, the world's largest supplier of fibre-optic components and modules, lowered its first-quarter sales guidance because of continuing weakness in its telecommunications markets.
The news hit French stocks like IT consultant Cap Gemini and telecoms equipment group Alcatel, which both sank more than 10 percent.

Dutch semiconductor equipment maker ASML shed 7.9 percent after several major investment banks cut their recommendations, target prices and earnings and sales forecasts for the firm. The tech index fell 3.1 percent.
Insurers were also under the cosh, with Munich Re particularly hard hit after sources said Schroder Salamon Smith Barney had downgraded it to "underweight" from "inline".

Elsewhere, Vivendi Environnement fell eight percent on news a sale of the utilities group is being studied by parent Vivendi Universal, as the crushed media empire prepares to outline its new strategy.
The German election result also weighed on the retail sector.

"Sentiment in retail companies focused on Germany seems to be suffering the most as the government recently decided to delay cuts in personal income tax until 2004," said Volker Borghoff, an equity strategist at HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt.
Metro fell 2.5 percent, while Karstadt Quelle lost 5.5 percent.
U.S. DATA

British Energy soared 84 percent on hopes the embattled nuclear power generator will be thrown a lifeline by the government past a looming deadline, given that bondholders have said they may offer fresh funds.
Later in the session attention will switch to economic data from the U.S. Lead indicators during August are expected to have dipped 0.1 percent.

The highlights of this week include the Federal Open Markets Committee Meeting on Tuesday. Wall Street is unanimous in expecting no change in policy from the Federal Reserve but analysts also look for it to warn of economic risks ahead. (Additional reporting by Alison Tudor)
